SubTopics: Use paper and digital maps to ask and answer geographic questions (e.g., Where are there patterns? Why there? So what?). Analyze how various map projections distort shape, area, distance, and direction (e.g., Mercator, Robinson, Peters).
Content: Look at the map.
problems/WIG8SS/media/1a.jpg
This map could ùóïùóòùó¶ùóß be used for which purpose?

A.Choice: to see the regions that states belong to

Key.Rationale: Regions are not shown on the map.

B.Choice: to check the time zones that cross the continent

Key.Rationale: Time zones are not shown on the map.

C.Choice: to determine the types of government of different states

Key.Rationale: Government systems are not shown on the map.

D.Choice: to determine relative locations of physical features on the continent

Key.Rationale: The map shows mountain ranges and rivers of North America, so the best use of this map would be to determine the relative locations of physical features of the continent.

SubTopics: Explain how the POV of the author can influence the meaning of a primary or secondary source.
Content: Read the excerpt from the Gettysburg Address.

:box:It is rather for us, the living, to be here dedicated to the great task remaining before us‚Äîthat, from these honored dead we take increased devotion to that cause for which they here, gave the last full measure of devotion‚Äîthat we here highly resolve that these dead shall not have died in vain; that the nation, shall have a new birth of freedom, and that government of the people[,] by the people[,] for the people, shall not perish from the earth.

	‚ÄîPresident Abraham Lincoln, Gettysburg Address, November 19, 1863
How did President Lincoln‚Äôs point of view affect his writing?

A.Choice: As president of the United States, he sought to negotiate a peace proposal.

B.Choice: As president of the United States, he sought to improve his image for the next election.

C.Choice: As commander in chief of the victorious army, he sought to inspire the living and honor the dead.

D.Choice: As the general of the victorious army, he sought new recruits to replace the men lost in the battle.

SubTopics: Explain patterns of change over time in the community, the state, the United States, and the world.
Content: What was one way American Indians were ùó†ùó¢ùó¶ùóß likely affected by the changes shown on the maps?

A.Choice: They were forced to move to urban areas to find factory jobs.

Key.Rationale: American Indians were not forced to work in factories.

B.Choice: They were resettled in other countries by the U.S. government.

Key.Rationale: There was never a program that relocated American Indians to another country.

C.Choice: They were no longer able to follow their traditional ways of life.

Key.Rationale: As American Indians lost their land it limited their ability to live the way they had in the past.

D.Choice: They were required to perform agricultural work in the Southeast.

Key.Rationale: American Indians were not forced to work in the agricultural industry.

SubTopics: Summarize the role culture plays in personal and group behavior. Categorize factors that contribute to cooperation and conflict among peoples of a country and/or the world (i.e., culture, language, religion, political beliefs).
Content: Despite the changes shown on the maps, which cultural contribution of American Indians has had the ùó†ùó¢ùó¶ùóß lasting impact on the United States?

A.Choice: taking clan or family names from the mother‚Äôs side

Key.Rationale: This is not common practice in the United States.

B.Choice: claiming private ownership of land to use it for profit

Key.Rationale: This option does not describe aspects of American Indian culture.

C.Choice: living in harmony with the natural world and conserving resources

Key.Rationale: American Indian practices of living in harmony with nature and conserving natural resources are things that many people in the United States still do today.

D.Choice: developing different social classes based on physical features and skills

Key.Rationale: This option does not describe aspects of American Indian culture.

SubTopics: Construct a mental map of regions and locate the major regions of the world and their physical and cultural features including continents, cities, countries, bodies of water, landforms, mountain ranges, and climate zones. Compare mental maps shaped by individual perceptions of people, places, regions, and environments.
Content: Look at the map.
problems/WIG8SS/media/5a.jpg
Based on your knowledge of social studies and your mental map of the geographical world, which statement ùóïùóòùó¶ùóß describes the location of the Middle East?

A.Choice: It is located to the northwest of B.

B.Choice: It is located on the same continent as A.

C.Choice: It is located west of F and southeast of E.

D.Choice: It is located south of C and northeast of D.

SubTopics: Identify patterns such as culture, prior knowledge, family, peers, school, communities, and personal interests that influence a person‚Äôs cognition, perception, and behavior.
Content: Read the definition in the box.
:box:trend: a general direction in which something is developing or changing
Why do new music trends become popular within an age group?

A.Choice: The trend is based on traditions.

B.Choice: The trend is based on family expectations.

C.Choice: The trend is based on personal experience.

D.Choice: The trend is based on social media and peer influence.

SubTopics: Analyze how technology interacts with the environment and how increased use of technology affects the burden and use of natural resources.
Content: Choose ùó¢ùó°ùóò cause and ùó¢ùó°ùóò consequence for the global issue.

SubTopics: Compare and contrast the role of different economic institutions such as banks, labor unions, non-profits, and businesses in an economy. Analyze rules and laws that protect and support both consumers (e.g., private property, zoning, contracts, agreements, and product safety) and workers (e.g., labor unions, regulations, minimum wage).
Content: How will the business shown in the image ùó†ùó¢ùó¶ùóß affect the standard of living in the community?

A.Choice: It will cost owners more in insurance and wages.

Key.Rationale: This option describes an effect of opening the business, but this would only affect the business owners.

B.Choice: It will create new jobs and generate tax revenue.

Key.Rationale: The new business will create jobs and pay taxes in the community. The increased tax revenue and reduction in unemployment should affect the standard of living in the community.

C.Choice: It will encourage more tourists to visit the community.

Key.Rationale: One business is unlikely to bring enough tourists to the area to affect the standard of living.

D.Choice: It will cause more grocery stores in the community to close.

Key.Rationale: The opening of this business will not lead to many grocery stores closing.

SubTopics: Categorize factors of production and how they are combined to make goods and deliver services. Evaluate how profits influence sellers in markets.
Content: Why did Susie ùó†ùó¢ùó¶ùóß likely open this business?

Key.Rationale: Most entrepreneurs open new businesses to earn a profit.
Although this is a goal of a new business, if the business does not remain profitable it will not be able employ people, share its goods, or bring new services to the community.

C.Choice: to bring new services to the community

Key.Rationale: Although this is a goal of a new business, if the business does not remain profitable it will not be able employ people, share its goods, or bring new services to the community.

D.Choice: to introduce new food to the community

Key.Rationale: Although this is a goal of a new business, if the business does not remain profitable it will not be able employ people, share its goods, or bring new services to the community.

SubTopics: Analyze the scope and limits of individual protections found in the Constitution and the Bill of Rights. Describe the evolution of rights over time including key laws, constitutional changes, and court decisions that contributed to these developments. Predict how collective action movements work to extend equal rights to groups and individuals.
Content: With which principle of the U.S. government does the Brown v. Board of Education of Topeka decision ùó†ùó¢ùó¶ùóß closely align?

Key.Rationale: This option is a basic principles of democracy, but it is not exhibited in the Brown v. Board decision.
This option is a basic principles of democracy, but it is not exhibited in the Brown v. Board decision.
The ruling in Brown v. Board of Education of Topeka ended the ‚Äúseparate but equal‚Äù policy and allowed people of all races to attend the same school.
This option is a basic principles of democracy, but it is not exhibited in the Brown v. Board decision.

SubTopics: Analyze the scope and limits of individual protections found in the Constitution and the Bill of Rights. Describe the evolution of rights over time including key laws, constitutional changes, and court decisions that contributed to these developments. Predict how collective action movements work to extend equal rights to groups and individuals.
Content: The U.S. Supreme Court ruled in favor of the African American plaintiffs in Brown v. Board of Education of Topeka. What did this decision eventually allow African American children to do?

Key.Rationale: African Americans could attend private schools in the past.
The decision in Brown v. Board of Education of Topeka allowed African Americans to attend schools that in the past were segregated as white schools.

C.Choice: attend schools in their own neighborhoods

Key.Rationale: Most schools segregated by race were in neighborhoods dominated by one of the races.

D.Choice: attend schools that were equal to those for whites

Key.Rationale: Prior to the ruling, schools segregated for African Americans were supposedly equal to those attended by white children.

SubTopics: Explain patterns of change over time in the community, the state, the United States, and the world.
Content: Which statement ùóïùóòùó¶ùóß describes the reason for the change between the two maps?

A.Choice: The United States acquired the land after a war with Spain.

Key.Rationale: This option describes how the United States acquired some of the land in the maps, not why the railroads expanded.

B.Choice: The United States signed a treaty with the British for use of the land.

Key.Rationale: This option describes how the United States acquired some of the land in the maps, not why the railroads expanded.

C.Choice: Factory owners in the United States needed a way to get natural resources faster.

Key.Rationale: The increase of railroads in the United States was driven by the need to get natural resources to factories faster.

D.Choice: Agricultural expansion in the United States relied on having a way to get workers to the fields faster.

Key.Rationale: At this time the primary use of railroads was not to get people to work faster.

SubTopics: Explain patterns of change over time in the community, the state, the United States, and the world.
Content: Which statement ùóïùóòùó¶ùóß describes an effect of the change shown between the maps?

A.Choice: Major urban areas became less important as trade centers.

Key.Rationale: Established trading centers did not lose their status, but railroads did increase the number of urban centers.

B.Choice: Port cities had less need of railroads than inland cities had.

Key.Rationale: The port cities were used to transport goods to places where railroads couldn‚Äôt go and were often a final destination of the railroads.

C.Choice: Sections of the country became less dependent on each other.

Key.Rationale: The railroads increased the interdependence of regions in the United States.

D.Choice: Economic opportunities increased in southern and western states.

Key.Rationale: When the railroads expanded, economic opportunities followed.
